datasetPresenter.name: Umay521_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Ustilago maydis 521 Sequence and Annotation
datasetPresenter.summary: Ustilago maydis is a ubiquitous pathogen of maize and a well-established model organism for the study of plant-microbe interactions. This basidiomycete fungus does not use aggressive virulence strategies to kill its host. U. maydis belongs to the group of biotrophic parasites (the smuts) that depend on living tissue for proliferation and development.
datasetPresenter.description: The Ustilago maydis sequence project is part of the Broad Institute's Fungal Genome Initiative and was accomplished through collaborations with the Broad Institute, Bayer CropScience AG and Exelixis, Inc. The goal of this project is to release 10X genomic coverage for U. maydis strain 521. Bayer CropScience contributed their low-coverage genome sequence of U. maydis strain 521. These data consist of 17.4 Mb in 28 contigs and were generated from a minimal tiling path of overlapping BAC clones that cover 23 chromosomes. Exelixis has provided 5X whole-genome shotgun sequences of U. maydis strain FB1 that is assembled and aligned against the WGS assembly of strain 521 to identify polymorphism between these two strains.
datasetPresenter.protocol: U. maydis strain 521 (a1 b1) was sequenced by two independent strategies, a whole genome shotgun (WGS) approach and a map-based sequencing strategy.

datasetPresenter.name: BdenJEL423_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis JEL423 Sequence and Annotation
datasetPresenter.summary: Batrachochytrium is a pathogen of amphibians implicated as a primary causative agent of amphibian declines. This recently emerging pathogen was identified in 1998 as the cause of amphibian deaths in Australia and Central America. More recently, Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis has been implicated in population declines of frog species in North America, South America, Europe and Africa. This fungus invades the top layers of skin cells and causes thickening of the keratinized layer. As a representative of the Chytridiomycota (chytrids), the sequence of B. dendrobatidis is the first in this largely uncharacterized phylum of fungi.
datasetPresenter.description: The Broad Institute sequenced the diploid Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis strain JEL423 genome at 7.4X coverage using whole genome shotgun (WGS) sequencing. The current assembly (Assembly 1) consists of 348 nuclear genome contigs in 69 supercontigs, and 3 mitochondrial genome contigs in 1 supercontig. The genome assembly will undergo automated annotation.
datasetPresenter.protocol: We produced whole genome shotgun sequence from two plasmid libraries (4kb and 10kb inserts) and a Fosmid library. The resulting 7.4X assembly was made public in September of 2006, and the results of automated genome annotation will be made public in future 2006 releases.

datasetPresenter.name: NcraOR74A_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Neurospora crassa OR74A Sequence and Annotation
datasetPresenter.summary: The approximately 40-megabase genome encodes about 10,000 protein-coding genes—more than twice as many as in the fission yeast Schizosaccharomyces pombe and only about 25% fewer than in the fruitfly Drosophila melanogaster
datasetPresenter.description: N crassa draft genome was sequenced, annotated and reported by the Broad Institute in collaboration with the Neurospora research community.
datasetPresenter.protocol:
The genome sequence was assembled from deep whole-genome shotgun (WGS) coverage obtained by paired-end sequencing from a variety of clone types.
Sequencing methods for all clone types are described at http://www-genome.wi.mit.edu/. The sequence was assembled using Arachne

datasetPresenter.name: PgraCRL75367003_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Puccinia graminis f. sp. tritici CRL75367003 Sequence and Annotation
datasetPresenter.summary: The pathogenic fungus Puccinia graminis causes stem rust in small cereal crops such as wheat, oat, rye, and barley. Stem rust, also referred to as black rust or black stem rust, is among the most destructive diseases of cereal crops and has resulted in enormous economic and yield losses. Puccinia graminis has a complex life cycle that includes five spore stages and two very different hosts, namely, a grass for the primary host and, most commonly, barberry as the alternate host. Puccinia graminis has a number of "special forms", or forma speciales (f. sp.), which differ in their primary host specificities.
datasetPresenter.description: The Puccinia graminis f. sp. tritici reference sequence (RefSeq) genome is provided by NCBI. It is a curated copy of the Puccinia graminis f. sp. tritici strain CRL 75-36-700-3 genome sequence submitted to INSD by the Broad Institute.
datasetPresenter.protocol: We produced whole genome shotgun sequence from two plasmid libraries (4kb and 10kb inserts) and a Fosmid library. The resulting 7X assembly was made public in January of 2007, and the results of automated genome annotation will be made public in future releases.

datasetPresenter.name: HcapNAm1_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Histoplasma capsulatum NAm1 Sequence and Annotation
datasetPresenter.summary: Histoplasma capsulatum is the most common cause of fungal respiratory infections (histoplasmosis) in the world. While most infections are mild, 10% of cases result in life-threatening complications such as inflammation of the pericardium and fibrosis of major blood vessels (Durkin, Kohler et al. 2001). In addition, some African H. capsulatum isolates cause a distinct disease, African histoplasmosis, that is characterized by cutaneous and subcutaneous lesions in the bone (Jones and Goodwin., 1981). Once infected, a latent infection may be reactivated. Histoplasma poses a particular threat to the elderly and to immunocompromised patients (Rachid, Rezende et al. 2003).
datasetPresenter.description: The Ajellomyces capsulatus reference sequence (RefSeq) genome is provided by the NCBI. It is a curated copy of the Ajellomyces capsulatus strain NAm1 genome sequence submitted to GenBank/EMBL/DDBJ by the Broad Institute.
datasetPresenter.protocol: For Histoplasma capsulatum class NAmI strain WU24, we produced whole genome shotgun sequence from two plasmid libraries (4kb and 10kb inserts) and a Fosmid library. The resulting 7X assembly was made public in September 2005, and the results of automated genome annotation was made public May, 2006.

datasetPresenter.name: HcapG186AR_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Histoplasma capsulatum G186AR Sequence and Annotation
datasetPresenter.summary: Histoplasma capsulatum is the most common cause of fungal respiratory infections (histoplasmosis) in the world. While most infections are mild, 10% of cases result in life-threatening complications such as inflammation of the pericardium and fibrosis of major blood vessels (Durkin, Kohler et al. 2001). In addition, some African H. capsulatum isolates cause a distinct disease, African histoplasmosis, that is characterized by cutaneous and subcutaneous lesions in the bone (Jones and Goodwin., 1981). Once infected, a latent infection may be reactivated. Histoplasma poses a particular threat to the elderly and to immunocompromised patients (Rachid, Rezende et al. 2003).
datasetPresenter.description: The Washington University School of Medicine (WashU), in collaboration with the Broad Institute and the University of California at San Francisco, sequenced the Histoplasma capsulatum strain G186AR genome at 6X coverage using whole genome shotgun (WGS) sequencing. Together with the 4X coverage provided by Broad Institute, the team built a high quality assembly that is currently being annotated.
datasetPresenter.protocol: The Latin American Histoplasma capsulatum class H81 strain G186AR was assembled from sequence reads produced by both the Broad Institute and the Washington University School of Medicine. Sequences were obtained from 454 pOT library beads and fosmid libraries containing 3.1kb, 4.1kb, 5.7 kb, and 39kb inserts. The resulting 10X assembly was made public in May 2008 and the results of automated genome annotation will be made public in future releases.

datasetPresenter.name: CgatR265_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Cryptococcus gattii R265 Sequence and Annotation
datasetPresenter.summary: C. gattii was initially classified as a variety of C. neoformans but has recently been recognized as a separate species. These pathogens are responsible for infections in immunocompromised and immunocompetent hosts.
datasetPresenter.description: The Cryptococcus gattii sequence was assembled by Kronstad Lab at at the University of British Columbia.

datasetPresenter.name: CgatWM276_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Cryptococcus gattii WM276 Sequence and Annotation
datasetPresenter.summary: C. gattii was initially classified as a variety of C. neoformans but has recently been recognized as a separate species. These pathogens are responsible for infections in immunocompromised and immunocompetent hosts.
datasetPresenter.description: The Cryptococcus gattii sequence was assembled by Kronstad Lab at at the University of British Columbia.

datasetPresenter.name: CneoB3501_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Cryptococcus neoformans B3501 Sequence and Annotation
datasetPresenter.description: C neoformans B3501 was sequenced at the Stanford Genome Technology Center

datasetPresenter.name: CneoJEC21_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Cryptococcus neoformans JEC21 Sequence and Annotation
datasetPresenter.description: C neoformans JEC21 genome was annotated and submitted to Genbank by TIGR

datasetPresenter.name: ScerS288c_primary_genome_RSRC

datasetPresenter.name: Ndis8579_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Neurospora discreta FGSC 8579 Sequence and Annotation
datasetPresenter.description: The current draft release was submitted by John Taylor et al. from University of California, Berkeley. The gene models are predicted and functionally annotated using the JGI annotation pipeline

datasetPresenter.name: Ntet2508A_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Neurospora tetrasperma FGSC 2508 mat A Sequence and Annotation
datasetPresenter.summary: N. tetrasperma is the only Neurospora species that employs a mating strategy that combines selfing with occasional outbreeding using a novel genetic system (pseudohomothallism) and provides a model for studying both the genomic and evolutionary consequences of asexuality and inbreeding.
datasetPresenter.description: Neurospora tetrasperma was sequenced and annotated at the JGI and the project has been submitted to Genbank under accession number AFBT00000000

datasetPresenter.name: AclaNRRL1_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Aspergillus clavatus Sequence and Annotation
datasetPresenter.description: The Aspergillus clavatus genome (strain NRRL1) has been sequenced by TIGR with funding provided by the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases (NIAID).

datasetPresenter.name: AflaNRRL3357_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Aspergillus flavus NRRL3357 Sequence and Annotation
datasetPresenter.description: The Aspergillus flavus genome was sequenced and annotated by William Nierman et al. from JCVI

datasetPresenter.name: AnigATCC1015_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Aspergillus niger ATCC 1015 Sequence and Annotation
datasetPresenter.description: Aspergillus niger ATCC 1015 annotaions was prepared by Hein Stam et al. from DSM, Netherlands

datasetPresenter.name: AnidA4_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Aspergillus nidulans FGSC A4 Sequence and Annotation
datasetPresenter.description: The A nidulans genome was sequenced and annotated and submitted to the Genbank by the Broad institute.

datasetPresenter.name: AfumAF293B_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Aspergillus fumigatus Af293 Sequence and Annotation
datasetPresenter.description: The Aspergillus fumigatus Af293 genome was sequenced and annotated by William Nierman et al. from JCVI

datasetPresenter.name: AterNIH2624_primary_genome_RSRC

datasetPresenter.description: The Aspergillus terreus NIH2624 genome was sequenced and annotated by William Nierman et al. from JCVI

datasetPresenter.description: Draft sequence of the Sordaria macrospora genome was prepared and submitted to GenBank by Minou Nowrousian, Jason Stajich et al.

datasetPresenter.name: CneoH99_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Cryptococcus neoformans H99 Sequence and Annotation
datasetPresenter.description: C neoformans H99 genome was annotated and submitted to Genbank by Fred Dietrich et al., from the Duke University

datasetPresenter.name: CalbSC5314_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Candida albicans SC5314 Sequence and Annotation
datasetPresenter.description: The C. albicans strain SC5314 genome sequence and diploid contig-level assembly by the Stanford Genome Technology Center

datasetPresenter.name: Foxy4287_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Fusarium oxysporum f. sp. lycopersici Sequence and Annotation
datasetPresenter.description: Fusarium oxysporum draft genome was sequenced, annotated and reported by the Broad Institute,

datasetPresenter.name: Mory7015_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Magnaporthe oryzae 70-15 Sequence and Annotation
datasetPresenter.description: Magnaporthe oryzae genome sequence was obtained from the Broad Institute,

datasetPresenter.name: CcinOk7h130_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Coprinopsis cinerea Ok7h130 Sequence and Annotation
datasetPresenter.summary: Coprinopsis cinerea, also known as Coprinus cinereus, is a multicellular basidiomycete that undergoes a complete sexual cycle, including typical mushroom formation. Extensive genetic and molecular analyses of this organism can be performed due to its easy cultivation on defined minimal media, making it a great model for studying development and regulation in multicellular organisms. The Coprinopsis cinerea genome is estimated at 37.5 Mb, organized in 13 chromosomes. Over 100 markers involved in mating type, hyphal growth, fruit body morphogenesis, and DNA repair have been assigned to 10 linkage groups. RFLP and RAPD markers are widely used.
datasetPresenter.description: The Coprinopsis cinerea reference sequence (RefSeq) genome is provided by NCBI. It is a curated copy of the Coprinopsis cinerea strain okayama 7#130 genome sequence submitted to GenBank/EMBL/DDBJ by the Broad institute. The Coprinopsis genome project is a partnership between the Broad Institute and the Coprinopsis research community. Genomic DNA for the genome project was provided by Patricia Pukkila at University of North Carolina.
datasetPresenter.protocol: Broad produced whole genome shotgun sequence from 4kb & 10kb plasmids and 40kb Fosmids.

datasetPresenter.name: Rory99880_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Rhizopus oryzae 99880 Sequence and Annotation
datasetPresenter.summary: Rhizopus oryzae is a widely dispersed fungus that can cause fatal infections in people with suppressed immune systems, especially diabetics or organ transplant recipients. Antibiotic therapy alone is rarely curative, particularly in patients with disseminated infection. We sequenced the genome of a pathogenic R. oryzae strain and found evidence that the entire genome had been duplicated at some point in its evolution and retained two copies of three extremely sophisticated systems involved in energy generation and utilization. The ancient whole-genome duplication, together with recent gene duplications, has led to the expansion of gene families related to pathogen virulence, fungal-specific cell wall synthesis, and signal transduction, which may contribute to the aggressive and frequently life-threatening growth of this organism. We also identified cell wall synthesis enzymes, essential for fungal cell integrity but absent in mammals, which may present potential targets for developing novel diagnostic and therapeutic treatments. R. oryzae represents the first sequenced fungus from the early lineages of the fungal phylogenetic tree, and thus the genome sequence sheds light on the evolution of the entire fungal kingdom.
datasetPresenter.description: The Rhizopus oryzae sequence project is part of the Fungal Genome Initiative at the Broad Institute of Harvard and MIT. The goal of this project is to release 10X sequence coverage for Rhizopus oryzae strain 99-880 (it also have been called RA 99-880). The strain was isolated in 1999 from a brain abscess of a diabetic patient who developed fatal rhinocerebral mucormycosis.
datasetPresenter.protocol: The genome sequence was assembled from 454 Whole Genome Shotgun methods using fragment and paired-end reads to iteratively build the supercontigs. The annotation was performed using automated methods.

datasetPresenter.name: CimmRS_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Coccidioides immitis RS Sequence and Annotation
datasetPresenter.description: Coccidioides immitis genome sequence was obtained from the Broad Institute,

datasetPresenter.name: CimmH5384_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Coccidioides immitis H538.4 Sequence and Annotation
datasetPresenter.description: Coccidioides immitis genome sequence was obtained from the Broad Institute,

datasetPresenter.name: CposC735_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Coccidioides posadasii C735 Sequence and Annotation
datasetPresenter.description: Reference sequence provided by NCBI. It is a curated copy of the Coccidiodes posadasii transgenic strain C735 delta SOWgp genome sequence submitted to INSDC by the J. Craig Venter Institute.

datasetPresenter.name: Fver7600_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Fusarium verticillioides 7600 Sequence and Annotation
datasetPresenter.description: Fusarium verticillioides genome sequence was obtained from the Broad Institute,

datasetPresenter.name: FgraPH1_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Fusarium graminearum PH-1 Sequence and Annotation
datasetPresenter.description: Fusarium graminearum PH-1 genome sequence was obtained from the Broad Institute,

datasetPresenter.name: PhysoP6497_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Phytophthora genome sequences uncover evolutionary origins and mechanisms of pathogenesis
datasetPresenter.description: Draft genome sequences of Phytophthora sojae and P. ramorum assembled and annotated by JGI and VBI. Please cite Tyler et al. (2006) Science. 313, 1261-1266

datasetPresenter.name: PhyraPr102_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Phytophthora genome sequences uncover evolutionary origins and mechanisms of pathogenesis
datasetPresenter.description: Draft genome sequences of Phytophthora sojae and P. ramorum assembled and annotated by JGI and VBI. Please cite Tyler et al. (2006) Science. 313, 1261-1266

datasetPresenter.name: HyaarEmoy2_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Signatures of adaptation to obligate biotrophy in the Hyaloperonospora arabidopsidis genome.
datasetPresenter.description: Hyaloperonospora arabidopsidis genome sequenced and assembled at WashU genome center and Sainsbury lab and annotated at VBI. Please cite Baxter, Tripathy et. al Science(2010) Vol. 330 no. 6010 pp. 1549-1551

datasetPresenter.name: PhyinT304_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Genome sequence and analysis of the Irish potato famine pathogen Phytophthora infestans.
datasetPresenter.description: Phytophthora infestans genome sequences annotated at the Broad Institute. Please cite Haas and kamoun et al. Nature 461, 393-398.

datasetPresenter.name: PhycaLT1534_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: The oomycete broad-host-range pathogen Phytophthora capsici.
datasetPresenter.description: Phytophthora capsici is a highly dynamic and destructive pathogen of vegetables. It attacks all cucurbits, pepper, tomato and eggplant, and, more recently, snap and lima beans. Genome sequences were assembled and annotated at the JGI.

datasetPresenter.name: PytulBR144_primary_genome_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Genome sequence of the necrotrophic plant pathogen Pythium ultimum reveals original pathogenicity mechanisms and effector repertoire.
datasetPresenter.description: Pythium ultimum is a ubiquitous oomycete plant pathogen responsible for a variety of diseases on a broad range of crop and ornamental species. Genome sequences were annotated at Michigan State University.Please cite Levesque et al. Genome Biol. 2010;11:R73.

datasetPresenter.name: CneoH99_OMeara_Alspaugh_H99_rnaSeq_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: C.neoformans RNASeq - Wild Type, nrg1 KO, and nrg1 overexpression
datasetPresenter.description: Unpublished Cryptococcus neoformans var. grubii H99 data from Teresea O'Meara et al. from Alspaugh Lab at Duke University on Wild Type, nrg1 KO, and nrg1 overexpression.

datasetPresenter.name: CneoH99_Haynes_capsuleRegulation_rnaSeq_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: C.neoformans - Transcriptome analysis of ada2, nrg1, cir1 and KN99
datasetPresenter.summary: Identify Cryptococcus neoformans genes based on Transcriptome analysis of ada2&Delta, nrg1&Delta and cir1&Delta and KN99&Alpha wildtype cells in capsule inducing and non-inducing conditions.
datasetPresenter.description: C.neoformans grubii H99 data from Brian Haynes et al. from Doering Lab at Washington University Medical School on ada2Δ, nrg1Δ and cir1Δ and KN99α wildtype expression.

datasetPresenter.name: CcinOk7h130_Stajich_HyphalGrowthTimeSeries_rnaSeq_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Ccin Hyphal Growth Time Series Rna Seq Expression Data
datasetPresenter.summary: Identify Coprinopsis cinerea genes based on fold change expression difference between a "comparison" and a "reference" sample.
datasetPresenter.description: Unpublished data from Stajich lab at UC Riverside representing hyphal sections from 2 time points (9 days and 15 days) of hyphal growth on solid media for Coprinopsis cinerea. This experiment is intended to compare genes expressed on the hyphal edge and in the colony.

datasetPresenter.name: Rory99880_Stajich_HyphalGrowthTimeSeries_rnaSeq_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Rory Hyphal Growth Time Series Rna Seq Expression Data
datasetPresenter.summary: Identify Rhizopus oryzae genes based on fold change expression difference between a "comparison" and a "reference" sample.
datasetPresenter.description: Unpublished data from Stajich lab at UC Riverside representing 3 time points (3hrs, 5hrs, and 20hrs) of hyphal growth on solid media for Rhizopus oryzae. The 3 hrs is the youngest tissue and from the hyphal tip while the 5 and 20 represent more interior to the colony and more mature tissue.

datasetPresenter.name: CimmRS_Taylor_ComparativeTranscriptomics_rnaSeq_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Cimm Comparative Transcriptomics Rna Seq Expression Data
datasetPresenter.summary: Comparative transcriptomics were used to identify gene expression differences between the saprobic and parasitic growth phases of Coccidiodes immitis and C. posadasii. Of the 9,910 total predicted genes in Coccidioides, 1,298 genes were observed to be up-regulated in the saprobic phase of both C. immitis and C. posadasii and 1,880 genes were observed to be up-regulated in the parasitic phase of both species
datasetPresenter.description: Comparative transcriptomics were used to identify gene expression differences between the saprobic and parasitic growth phases. The results highlighted a number of genes that may be crucial to dimorphic phase-switching and virulence in Coccidioides.
datasetPresenter.protocol: Illumina mRNA sequencing libraries for saprobic-phase hyphae and parasitic-phase spherules in vitro for C. immitis isolate RS and C. posadasii isolate C735 were prepared in biological triplicate

datasetPresenter.name: CposC735_Taylor_ComparativeTranscriptomics_rnaSeq_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Cpos Comparative Transcriptomics Rna Seq Expression Data
datasetPresenter.summary: Comparative transcriptomics were used to identify gene expression differences between the saprobic and parasitic growth phases of Coccidiodes immitis and C. posadasii. Of the 9,910 total predicted genes in Coccidioides, 1,298 genes were observed to be up-regulated in the saprobic phase of both C. immitis and C. posadasii and 1,880 genes were observed to be up-regulated in the parasitic phase of both species
datasetPresenter.description: Comparative transcriptomics were used to identify gene expression differences between the saprobic and parasitic growth phases. The results highlighted a number of genes that may be crucial to dimorphic phase-switching and virulence in Coccidioides.
datasetPresenter.protocol: Illumina mRNA sequencing libraries for saprobic-phase hyphae and parasitic-phase spherules in vitro for C. immitis isolate RS and C. posadasii isolate C735 were prepared in biological triplicate

datasetPresenter.name: NcraOR74A_hyphalgrowth_Stajich_rnaSeq_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Neurospora crassa OR74A Expression Data
datasetPresenter.summary: This study compared gene expression from 3 different time points in hyphal growth by cutting 1 cm strip of tissue from the hyphal tip (3hrs old), several cm back (5hrs old) and further back in the colony (20hrs old) in Neurospora crassa OR74A growing on VM media
datasetPresenter.description: Unpublished data from Stajich lab at UC Riverside representing 3 time points (3hrs, 5hr, and 20hrs) of hyphal growth on solid media for Neurospora crassa.

datasetPresenter.name: NcraOR74A_Ellison_PopulationGenomics_rnaSeq_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: N crassa population genomics
datasetPresenter.summary: This study uses a "reverse-ecology" population genomic approach to identify ecologically relevant phenotypes in organisms that are difficult to study in nature.
datasetPresenter.description: Neurospora crasss data from Christopher Ellison et al. from Taylor Lab at at UC Berkeley on whole-transcriptome sequencing of 48 individuals to identify SNPs

datasetPresenter.name: CalbSC5314_Snyder_comprehensiveAnnotation_rnaSeq_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: RNA-Seq Expression - C albicans Comprehensive Annotation
datasetPresenter.summary: Massively parallel high-throughput sequencing of cDNA was used to generate a high-resolution map of the C. albicans transcriptome under several different environmental conditions. The regions that are transcribed under the different conditions have been quantitatively determined and 635 novel transcriptionally active regions (TARs) and numerous novel introns have bben identified
datasetPresenter.description: Candida albicans data from Michael Snyder et al. from Synder Lab at Stanford University on Comprehensive Annotation of the transcriptome of the human fugal pathogen Candida albicans using RNA-Seq
datasetPresenter.protocol: Data has been generated for C. albicans (strain SC5314) grown under a total of nine different in vitro conditions. Using our data set of about 177 million mapped reads, we have significantly refined the primary annotations of the C. albicans genome by determining the position of transcripts in the genomes, including 602 newly identified transcripts for strain SC5314, and by identifying 41 new introns.

datasetPresenter.name: Spom972hm_Barraud_dicerProtein_rnaSeq_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: RNA-Seq Expression - S pombe Dicer Protein
datasetPresenter.summary: Dicer proteins function in RNA interference (RNAi) pathways by generating small RNAs (sRNAs). The solution structure of the C-terminal domain of Schizosaccharomyces pombe Dicer (Dcr1) is reported here. The C-terminal domain of Dcr1 constitutes a novel regulatory module that might represent a potential target for therapeutic intervention with fungal diseases.
datasetPresenter.description: Schizosaccharomyces pombe data from Pierre Barraud, Marc Buhler et al. from ETH Zurich and FMI Basel on nuclear retention of fission yeast Dicer
datasetPresenter.protocol: Small RNA libraries from total RNA isolations of wild-type, dcr1Delta, dcr1SHSS, and dcr1Deltaloop2 cells and subjected to high-throughput sequencing.

datasetPresenter.name: ScerS288c_microarrayExpression_Spellman_CellCycle_1998_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Microarray Expression - Expression profiling of saccharomyces cerevisiae s288c
datasetPresenter.summary: The following experiments from Spellman et. al. : (1) Pheromone synchronization time course, (2) Size-based synchronization time course (elutriation), (3) Cdc15-based synchronization time course, (4) Transcriptional response to the cyclins Cln3p and Clb2p. The following experiment is from Cho et. al. Cdc28-based synchronization time course
datasetPresenter.description: Saccharomyces cerevisiae cell cycle regulation microarray data

datasetPresenter.name: PhysoP6497_Physo_rnaseq_rnaSeq_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: P. sojae expression during infection
datasetPresenter.summary: This study has 2 experimental replicates and each one has 4 biological replicates. The first replicate is from P. sojae mycelial tissue sample grown in media and the second replicate is from Soybean hypocotyls infected with P. sojae 3 dpi.
datasetPresenter.description: This study has 2 experimental replicates and each one has 4 biological replicates. The first replicate is from P. sojae mycelial tissue sample grown in media and the second replicate is from Soybean hypocotyls infected with P. sojae 3 dpi.

datasetPresenter.name: PhyraPr102_Phyra_rnaseq_rnaSeq_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Phytophthora ramorum transcript profiling during sporulation and V8 liquid medium and Tomato broth
datasetPresenter.summary: Phytophthora ramorum transcript profiling in zoospore, chlamydospore , V8 medium and tomato broth
datasetPresenter.description: Phytophthora ramorum transcript profiling in zoospore, chlamydospore , V8 m edium and tomato broth

datasetPresenter.name: HyaarEmoy2_Hyaar_rnaseq_rnaSeq_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: Signatures of adaptation to obligate biotrophy in the Hyaloperonospora arabidopsidis genome.
datasetPresenter.description: Illumina sequencing was performed using RNA from four week old Arabidopsis Ws-2 eds1-1 leaves, highly colonized with Emoy2, at 7 days post-inoculation at 60% humidity to promote mycelial growth in the mesophyll over sporulation .

datasetPresenter.displayName: Candida albicans SC5314 External DB Reference - CGD
datasetPresenter.description: Candida Genome Database(CGD)

datasetPresenter.displayName: External DB Reference - CADRE

datasetPresenter.name: AnidA4_dbxref_unity_BroadInstitute_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: External DB Reference - Broad

datasetPresenter.name: AfumAF293B_dbxref_unity_BroadInstitute_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: External DB Reference - Broad

datasetPresenter.name: AnidA4_dbxref_unity_EnsemblFungi_RSRC
datasetPresenter.displayName: External DB Reference - Ensembl
